of the same, or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be
directed by the Mayor and Council. (Ord. 1724, 3-19-2002; amd. Ord. 3059, 5-6-
2014)
7-3A-5: DUTY OF CITY TREASURER:
The City Treasurer shall receive all such revenues from said service charges
and all other funds and monies incident thereto as the same may be delivered to
him and deposit the same in the general fund, garbage department of the city
and said treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner
provided by the provisions of the Illinois municipal code, effective July 1,
1961, and all laws amendatory thereof and supplementary thereto. Revenues so
received shall be used solely to defray the cost of operation, maintenance, and
service of a depreciation fund of the city garbage department.
The city treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep
proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall
be made of all transactions relative to the garbage department fund, and at
regular annual intervals he shall cause to be made an audit by an independent
auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the
fund. (Ord. 1073, 7-16-1985; amd. Ord. 3059, 5-6-2014)
7-3A-6: GUIDELINES, RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The streets and garbage committee is hereby tasked with the responsibility of
developing and promulgating written guidelines, rules and regulations to be
used in the implementation and perpetuation of said service charge.
The levy of such a service charge to be collected from persons receiving
garbage service is reasonably expected to yield revenues to properly fund the
cost of operation, maintenance, and an adequate depreciation fund for the city
garbage department. (Ord. 1073, 7-16-1985; amd. Ord. 1724, 3-19-2002; Ord.
3059, 5-6-2014)
CHAPTER 4
WATER WELLS
SECTION:
7-4-1: Definitions
7-4-2: Water Wells Prohibited; Existing Wells
7-4-3: Memorandum Of Understanding
7-4-4: Penalty
7-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
COMMUNITY WATER SUPPLY: A public water supply which serves or is intended to
serve at least fifteen (15) service connections used by residents or regularly
serves at least twenty five (25) residents.
CONTAMINANT: Any solid, liquid, or gaseous matter, any odor, or any form of
energy, from whatever source.
GROUND WATER: Underground water which occurs within the saturated zone and
geologic materials where the fluid pressure in the pore space is equal to or
greater than atmospheric pressure.
NONCOMMUNITY PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY: A public water supply that is not a community
water supply.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited
liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust,
estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal
representatives, agents or assigns.
POTABLE: Generally fit for human consumption in accordance with accepted water
supply principles and practices.
POTENTIAL ROUTE: Abandoned and improperly plugged wells of all kinds, drainage
wells, all injection wells, including closed looped heat pump wells, and
excavation for the discovery, development or production of stone, sand or
gravel.
PRIVATE WATER SYSTEM: Any supply which provides water for drinking, culinary,
and sanitary purposes and serves an owner occupied single-family dwelling.
PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY: All mains, pipes and structures through which water is
obtained and distributed to the public, including wells and well structures,
intakes and cribs, pumping stations, treatment plants, reservoirs, storage
tanks and appurtenances, collectively or severally, actually used or intended
for use for the purpose of furnishing water for drinking or general domestic
use and which serve at least fifteen (15) service connections or which
regularly serve at least twenty five (25) persons at least sixty (60) days per
year. A public water supply is either a "community water supply" or a
"noncommunity water supply".
SEMIPRIVATE WATER SYSTEM: A water supply which is not a public water system,
yet which serves a segment of the public other than an owner occupied single-
family dwelling. (Ord. 1794, 4-20-2004)
7-4-2: WATER WELLS PROHIBITED; EXISTING WELLS:
   (A)   Use of ground water as a private, semiprivate, noncommunity public
water supply, or community water supply not under the control of the city of
Canton, Illinois, is prohibited.
   (B)   Except for such uses of potable drinking water wells that are properly
constructed and are in existence before the effective date hereof, the use or
attempt to use a potable water well supply of ground water from within the
corporate limits of the city of Canton, Illinois, by the installation or
drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited, except at points
of withdrawal by the city of Canton, Illinois. (Ord. 1794, 4-20-2004)
7-4-3: MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING:
The mayor of the city of Canton, Illinois, is hereby authorized and directed to
enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Illinois environmental
protection agency in which the city of Canton, Illinois, assumes responsibility
for tracking remedial sites, notifying the Illinois EPA of changes to this
chapter and taking certain precautions when siting public potable water supply
wells. (Ord. 1794, 4-20-2004)
7-4-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine
of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. (Ord. 1794, 4-20-
2004)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
PUBLIC WORKS ADMINISTRATION
SECTION:
8-1-0: Public Works Director
8-1-1: Department Of Public Works
8-1-2: Board Of Local Improvements
8-1-3: City Engineer; Assistant
8-1-4: Superintendent Of Streets
8-1-5: System Maintenance Superintendent
8-1-0: PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR:
   (A)   Establishment; Appointment: A full time position of public works
director is hereby established. The public works director shall be appointed by
the mayor with concurrence of the city council.
   (B)   Duties: The public works director will supervise the street
superintendent, system maintenance superintendent, water superintendent,
wastewater superintendent, and the zoning officer. The public works director
will also be required to attend all city council and committee meetings. (Ord.
1743, 12-17-2002)
8-1-1: DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
There is hereby established an executive department of the city government,
which shall be known as the department of public works, and shall embrace the
board of local improvements, the city engineer, the superintendent of streets,
the superintendent of water and sewer distributions, the chief operators of the
water treatment plant and sewage treatment plant and such assistants and
employees as the city council may provide. (Ord. 593, 7-5-1977)
8-1-2: BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS:
There is hereby established and created a board of local improvements of the
city, which shall embrace and consist of the mayor, who shall be president of
said board, the city engineer, the superintendent of streets, and the city
attorney, which board is especially charged with performing all such duties
relating to local improvements to be paid wholly or in part by special
assessment or special taxation, as the laws of the state may impose or devolve
upon it. The clerk shall be the clerk of said board and shall keep a full and
correct record of its proceedings in a book to be provided for that purpose.
(Ord. 865, 1-20-1981)
8-1-3: CITY ENGINEER; ASSISTANT:
   (A)   Office Created, Appointment: There is hereby created the office of
city engineer of the city who shall be registered under the provisions of the
Illinois professional engineering act who shall be appointed by the mayor, by
and with the advice and consent of the council on the first Tuesday in May of
each year, or as soon thereafter as may be, and shall hold his office for the
term of one year, and until his successor is duly appointed and qualified.
   (B)   Oath, Bond: He shall, before entering upon the duties of his office,
take and subscribe the oath prescribed by law for the city officers, and shall
execute a bond to the city in the penal sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00), with sureties to be approved by the council, conditioned for the
faithful performance of the duties of his office.
   (C)   Duties:
      1.   Said engineer shall have charge of all public improvements,
commenced or to be commenced by the city which are to be paid for in whole or
in part by special assessment or special taxation, and such other public
improvements as require the skill of a civil engineer. He shall have special
charge of the construction and inspection of all public and private sewers and
catch basins laid on or in any public street, alley or way, and of the
construction and repair of all bridges and viaducts constructed by the city.
      2.   The city engineer shall advise the city on all engineering matters;
he shall, when required, advise the city council or any city officer in all
matters of engineering, in which the interest of the corporation are involved.
He shall, when required by the mayor, council, or any committee thereof,
furnish written opinions upon any subject submitted to him pertaining to the
city or its interests.
      3.   The city engineer shall draw and examine such plans, specifications,
and other papers as may be required of him by the mayor, council or any
committee thereof, and he shall examine and pass upon the engineering
sufficiency of any and all plans, specifications, and papers submitted to him
pertaining to the city or its interests, when required by the mayor, council,
or any committee thereof.
   (D)   Submit Estimates And Specifications: The city engineer shall, when
requested by the mayor, the board of local improvements, the council or any
committee thereof, make out and submit plans, estimates and specifications for
public work, which may be proposed or ordered by the council or the board of
local improvements.
   (E)   Superintend Public Works: He shall daily or as often as may be
necessary, examine all public works under his charge and see that the same is
properly executed, and if the contractor therefor shall neglect or refuse to
execute such work in accordance with his contract and specifications, said
engineer may suspend the work, and shall, thereupon, report the facts to the
mayor.
   (F)   Inspect Materials: He shall, when required, receive, inspect or
measure any lumber, brick, stone or other material to be used in any public
work of the city, and, if necessary, shall keep an accurate account of the
quantity or quality of the same, the cost thereof, of whom received and for
what purpose used or to be used, and he shall examine all bills for materials
so received by him, and, if found correct, shall certify the same to the
council for allowance.
   (G)   Establish Grades And Boundaries: He shall, when required by the
council of the committee on streets and alleys thereof, make a survey of the
grade or boundary of any street, avenue or alley of the city, and prepare a
plat or profile thereof and report the same to the council, and no such survey
or grade or boundary shall be deemed established or valid until the plat or
profile shall be approved by the council. Any plat, profile or other paper
belonging to the office of the city engineer shall be returned to him by the
clerk as soon as the council shall have no further use of the same.
   (H)   Furnish Grades, Make Surveys: He shall give or mark the grade of any
street or alley, where established, for any person desiring to erect any
building or enclosure or to lay any sidewalk thereon, when directed to do so by
the council. He shall make all surveys within and for the city when called
upon.
   (I)   Field Notes, Errors: It shall be the duty of the city engineer to
provide himself, so far as practicable, with copies of field notes of the
original surveys of the town and city of Canton, and to make his own surveys in
accordance therewith; he shall carefully note all errors or discrepancies in
the original surveys or resurveys as soon as discovered.
   (J)   Plats, Surveys Or Sewers And Water Mains: Said engineer shall keep in
his office plats of all grades or boundaries of streets and alleys established
by the council, correcting the same when any grade shall be changed, and adding
thereto when any new grade or boundary shall be established. He shall also keep
correct surveys of all public sewers and water mains within the city, showing
the location, length and dimensions of the same, respectively. He shall record
in a suitable book, to be provided by the city, the profiles of all surveys of
grades and boundaries established, and preserve the original papers relating
thereto, and shall otherwise keep a systematic record of all the transactions
pertaining to his office.
   (K)   Other Duties: He shall also perform such other duties as may be
required of him by the board of local improvements and the mayor or council in
the prosecution and construction of any public improvements within or under the
control of the city, as shall require the skill and experience of a civil
engineer.
   (L)   Assistants: He shall be allowed such assistants and other clerks and
subordinate help as the necessities of his office may require, and the council,
by ordinance or resolution, shall from time to time authorize him to employ.
   (M)   Monthly Reports: It shall be the duty of said engineer to make
monthly, written reports to the city treasurer and city clerk of all monies
received by his office arising from any official act, and to pay over to the
city treasurer, at least once each month, all monies so received by him.
He shall likewise make a monthly written report at the first meeting of the
council in each month of the monies so received by him and of all his acts and
doings for the preceding month.
   (N)   Annual Reports: The city engineer shall annually, on or before the
first Tuesday in May of each year, make out and submit to the council a written
report showing in detail the public works or improvements undertaken or
completed in connection with his office during the preceding fiscal year, and
the cost thereof to the city.
   (O)   Preserve Papers And Turn Over To Successor: Said engineer shall
carefully preserve in his office all plats and records of surveys, and all
books, maps and papers pertaining thereto, and upon expiration of his term of
office, or his resignation or removal therefrom, he shall deliver to his
successor in office all such books, maps, plats, records and effects of every
description belonging to the city or appertaining to said office.
   (P)   Office Hours: The office hours of the city engineer shall be from
eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. until twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and from one
o'clock (1:00) P.M. until five o'clock (5:00) P.M. from Monday through Friday.
(Ord. 1279, 5-1-1990)
   (Q)   Building Official/Zoning Enforcement Officer: The city engineer shall
perform the functions of building official under the various uniform codes as
the same may be from time to time adopted by the city; further, the city
engineer shall act as the zoning enforcement officer and shall cause the
various zoning laws to be faithfully enforced. As the building official and as
the zoning enforcement officer, he shall act as a staff advisor to the joint
planning and zoning commission. He shall give written opinions and reports when
requested to do so by the chairman of the joint planning and zoning commission.
He shall cause written variances to issue in conformity with the decisions of
the joint planning and zoning commission. (Ord. 1279, 5-1-1990; amd. Ord. 3041,
12-3-2013)
8-1-4: SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS:
   (A)   Office Created, Appointment: There is hereby created the office of
superintendent of streets of the city, who shall be appointed by the mayor, by
and with the advice and consent of the council, on the first Tuesday in May of
each year, or as soon thereafter as may be, and shall hold his office for the
term of one year, and until his successor is duly appointed and qualified.
(1959 Code § 36-5-1)
   (B)   Oath, Bond: Said superintendent shall, before entering upon the duties
of his office, take and subscribe the oath prescribed by law for city officers,
and shall execute a bond to the city in the penal sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00), with sureties to be approved by the city council, conditioned for
the faithful performance of the duties of his office. (1959 Code § 36-4-2)
   (C)   Powers: The superintendent of streets shall have the power, subject to
the provisions of this code and the orders of the mayor, to regulate and
control the manner of using the streets, alleys, highways and public places of
the city for the erection of telegraph poles, or other poles or posts; for the
laying down of gas, water or steam pipes and conduits and such other
underground construction authorized by law or the provisions of this code, as
are not under the control of the city engineer, and to determine the location
thereof and to cause the prompt repair of the streets, alleys, highways and
public places, whenever the same are taken up or altered. (Ord. 1280, 5-1-1990)
   (D)   Duties: The said superintendent shall, subject to the provisions
hereof, and the provisions of this code, take special charge and
superintendence of all streets, alleys and highways in the city, and of all
walks, crosswalks and public grounds and parks in the city; he shall have
charge of the repair and cleaning of all streets, avenues and alleys of the
city, and shall supervise the construction and repair of all sidewalks therein.
He shall, without delay, cause all breaks in any street or alley crossing or
other unsafe place to be repaired. (Ord. 865, 1-20-1981)
   (E)   Purchase Implements And Material; Mark Implements: He may procure the
necessary implements for performing street labor or materials for bridges,
culverts and crosswalks, but he shall purchase no implement of any material
without making a written requisition to the mayor and obtaining his order
therefor, and when he shall purchase any implements or materials for the use of
the corporation, he shall report the bill therefor to the council. He shall
cause all implements or tools belonging to the city to be legibly marked or
branded with the letters "Canton", and shall cause them to be properly housed
or protected from the weather when not in use. (1959 Code § 36-4-5)
   (F)   Keep List Of Property, Turn Over To Successor: It shall be the duty of
the superintendent of streets to keep a correct list of all implements,
material and other property of the city in his charge and possession, and upon
the expiration of his term of office, or his resignation or removal therefrom,
he shall deliver said property to his successor in office, taking a receipt
therefor, which he shall immediately file with the clerk, who shall credit him
with the same and charge his successor therewith. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 4,
Sec. 6)
   (G)   Books Of Account: It shall be the duty of said superintendent to cause
to be kept in books of account, in such manner as may be required by the
finance and personnel committee, a plain and accurate account of all
expenditures made under his supervision, specifying to whom and for what
purpose made. He shall examine all accounts of contractors and other persons
for work pertaining to his department, or for implements or material furnished
therefor, and if correct, shall certify the same to the council for allowance.
(Ord. 865, 1-20-1981)
   (H)   Monthly Report: Said superintendent of streets shall, on the first
Tuesday in each and every month, report to the council in writing a statement
of all expenditures under his supervision during the preceding month specifying
the purpose of such expenditures, and, if required, the persons to whom paid.
No account presented or certified by him shall be allowed, or warrants issued
thereon, unless it shall be so rendered as to show to what account it is
chargeable. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 4, Sec. 8)
   (I)   Enforcement, Orders: He shall cause all provisions in relation to
streets, alleys and sidewalks to be enforced, by reporting all violations
thereof to the mayor or chief of police. He shall carry into effect all such
orders, general or special, as he may receive from the council, the mayor or
committee on streets and alleys, and for any wilful neglect or refusal to
perform any duty required of him by the laws or provisions of this code, he
shall be liable to removal from office. He shall perform such other duties as
shall be enjoined upon him by the provisions of this code or by law directed.
(R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 4, Sec. 9)
   (J)   Employ Laborers, Keep Time: The street superintendent, upon
appointment of the mayor and the advice and consent of the city council, may
employ the following number of full time persons in the street and garbage
departments:
      1.   Street department: Seven (7) full time laborers.
      2.   Garbage department: Three (3) full time laborers.
However, nothing herein shall be construed to preclude the street
superintendent from hiring part time personnel on an "as needed" basis by
appointment of the mayor and the advice and consent of the appropriate
committee. He shall oversee and direct the laborers and workmen under his
authority and require them to labor faithfully. He shall keep a written record
of each such employee's time at work and shall, weekly, certify such record to
the city clerk as his weekly payroll, stating therein the name of each
employee, his weekly time, and the amount of his wages. The city clerk shall
draw an order upon the city treasurer to each employee for such amount. (Ord.
977, 5-31-1983)
8-1-5: SYSTEM MAINTENANCE SUPERINTENDENT:
   (A)   Appointment: A system maintenance superintendent shall be appointed by
the mayor with concurrence of the city council.
   (B)   Duties: The system maintenance superintendent shall:
      1.   Systematically review the conditions and plans, supervise the
maintenance of storm sewers, water lines and sanitary sewers;
      2.   Prepare and monitor an annual budget/expenditure, a vehicle/truck/
heavy equipment fleet and associated equipment and recommend capital
requirements to the public works director;
      3.   Direct and provide guidance to subordinates relating to maintenance,
repair and construction of public works department; and
      4.   Perform any other duties assigned by the public works director or
mayor and city council. (Ord. 1745, 12-17-2002)
CHAPTER 2
CONTRACTS AND CONTRACTORS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Contracts, How Made
8-2-2: City Engineer To Prepare Plans
8-2-3: Mayor To Advertise For Bids
8-2-4: Proposals, Awarding Contract
8-2-5: Contractor's Bond
8-2-6: Failure To Enter Into Contract, Disability
8-2-7: Officers Not To Be Interested In Contract
8-2-8: Contracts, How Executed
8-2-9: Contracts, Essential Clauses
8-2-10: Contractor's Liability
8-2-11: Disposal Of Surplus Material
8-2-12: Payments To Contractors
8-2-13: Payments For Extra Work
8-2-1: CONTRACTS, HOW MADE:
All contracts for the making of any public improvements in the city, to be paid
for in whole or in part by special assessment or special taxation, and any work
or other public improvement, when the expense thereof shall exceed the sum of
twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), shall be let to the lowest responsible
bidder therefor, in the manner hereinafter prescribed, and be approved by the
mayor. (Ord. 1726, 5-7-2002; amd. Ord. 1854, 1-3-2006)
8-2-2: CITY ENGINEER TO PREPARE PLANS:
Whenever any local or public improvements shall be ordered by the council,
which are to be paid for in whole or in part by special assessment or special
taxation or otherwise, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to prepare a
plan or profile of the proposed improvement and specifications for the
construction of the same, which shall be kept on file in his office, and be
open to the inspection of city officers and other persons interested therein.
(R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 5, Sec. 2)
8-2-3: MAYOR TO ADVERTISE FOR BIDS:
As soon as the special tax or special assessment for any such improvement shall
have been finally confirmed, as provided by law, and sooner if deemed expedient
by the mayor and council, the mayor is authorized to advertise, in one or more
newspapers of general circulation printed or published in the city, for
proposals to furnish materials and do said work, according to the plans and
specifications aforesaid. Such advertisement shall be published at least ten
(10) days before the date fixed for opening said proposals, and shall state the
nature and extent of the improvement ordered, the place where specifications
thereof may be seen, and the time and place when and where the bids will be
opened. The right to reject any and all proposals so received shall be reserved
in the advertisement. (Ord. 871, 2-17-1981)
8-2-4: PROPOSALS, AWARDING CONTRACT:
All proposals for any such improvement shall be signed by the persons bidding
and be enclosed in a sealed envelope, and directed to the mayor, and each bid
shall be accompanied by a cashier's check, bid bond and/or cash in such
reasonable amount as may be designated by the mayor in said advertisement,
payable to the order of the city treasurer, which shall become forfeited to the
city in case the bidder shall fail to enter into contract, and execute bond
with approved securities, to execute work for the price mentioned in his bid,
and according to the plans and specifications, in the event that the contract
should be awarded to him.
All proposals shall be opened by the mayor at the hour and place mentioned in
said advertisement, in the presence of such qualified bidders and other persons
as may attend, and, upon examination of the same, the city council shall award
the contract to the lowest qualified responsible bidder, or they may reject any
or all bids if the same are not satisfactory. (Ord. 871, 2-17-1981)
8-2-5: CONTRACTOR'S BOND:
Whenever any work or material is let by contract to any person or corporation,
the mayor shall, in all cases, take good and sufficient bond from such person
or corporation to ensure the performance of the work in the time and manner
required in such contract, and to save and indemnify and keep harmless against
all liabilities, judgments, costs and expenses which may in anywise accrue
against the city in consequence of granting of such contract, or which may in
anywise result from the carelessness or neglect of such person or corporation,
or his or its agents, employees or workmen, in any respect whatever, and the
payment of all labor and material claims growing or arising out of such work.
(R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 5, Sec. 5)
8-2-6: FAILURE TO ENTER INTO CONTRACT, DISABILITY:
Any bidder who shall fail to enter into any contract so awarded, or shall fail
to fulfill any contract entered into by him with the city, shall not be
permitted to bid again for any city work unless the council shall, for good
cause shown, remove his disability. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 5, Sec. 6)
8-2-7: OFFICERS NOT TO BE INTERESTED IN CONTRACT:
No member of the council or other city officer shall be interested, either
directly or indirectly, in any contract for work of the corporation, or become
surety for any contractor or other person upon any bond to secure the
performance of any contract with the city. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 5, Sec. 7)
8-2-8: CONTRACTS, HOW EXECUTED:
All such contracts and bonds shall run to and be in the name of the city, and
shall be drawn by the city attorney or be submitted to him for his approval of
the form thereof, and before the same shall be in force they shall be signed by
the mayor and countersigned and the corporate seal affixed by the city clerk.
Said contract shall be executed in duplicate, one original copy of which shall
be given to the contractor, and the other filed and kept in the office of the
city clerk, who shall furnish copies thereof when required. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36,
Art. 5, Sec. 8)
8-2-9: CONTRACTS, ESSENTIAL CLAUSES:
Each contract shall contain a clause, in substance to the effect that it is
made subject to the provisions of this code, and to the power of the mayor,
city engineer or other designated city officer to suspend the work and of the
city council to annul the contract for a failure on the part of the contractor
to execute the same according to the terms thereof, but that such suspension
shall not affect the right to all damages claimable by it on account of the
nonperformance of such contract according to the terms thereof.
All contracts in which the contractor or contractors agree to be paid from
special taxes or special assessments, shall contain certain covenants to the
effect that they shall have no claim or lien upon the city, in any event,
except from the collection of the special taxes or assessment levied for the
work contracted, and that no liability shall attach to the city by reason of
entering into any such contract, except to the payment to such contractor or
contractors of the monies received by the city on special taxes or assessments
levied or assessed for the improvement mentioned in such contract. And no
contract for work to be paid for as aforesaid shall be let to any contractor
who will not so agree. (Ord. 871, 2-17-1981)
8-2-10: CONTRACTOR'S LIABILITY:
Whenever any city officer shall let any work or improvement which shall require
the digging up, use or occupancy of any street, alley, highway or public ground
of the city, there shall be inserted in the contract for the same, substantial
covenants requiring such contractor, during the nighttime, to put up and
maintain such barriers and lights as will effectually prevent the happening of
any accident in consequence of such digging up, use or occupancy of any such
street, alley, highway or public grounds, for which the city might be liable,
and also such other covenants and conditions as experience may prove necessary
to save the city harmless from damages. And also to provide in such contract
that the party contracting with the city shall be liable for all damages
occasioned by the digging up, use or occupancy of such street, alley, highway
or public grounds, or which may result therefrom or which may result from the
carelessness of such contractor, his agents, employees or workmen. (R.O. 1959,
Ch. 36, Art. 5, Sec. 10)
8-2-11: DISPOSAL OF SURPLUS MATERIAL:
In all contracts for street and alley improvement, where the city shall reserve
the disposition of all surplus earth removed in excavations on such streets or
alleys, no contractor or subcontractor shall in any manner sell or dispose of
any such surplus earth, under a penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00)
for each offense. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 5, Sec. 11)
8-2-12: PAYMENTS TO CONTRACTORS:
When any contract shall have been completed, and on the filing in the office of
the city clerk of the certificate of the city engineer or other officer under
whose supervision the work was done, stating that he has inspected said work,
and that it is done according to the contract and specifications, the mayor and
clerk may issue their warrants on the treasurer for the amount due such
contractor or contractors; and they may, when so stipulated in the contract, or
with the consent of the council, from time to time during the prosecution of
the work (upon the filing of the certificate of the proper officer, stating
that he has examined and computed or measured such work, and that he believes
that there is enough done to cover the estimate, and that it is done in
accordance with the contract), advance to the contractor and draw their warrant
upon the treasurer for such advance, reserving, in all cases, at least five
percent (5%) of the estimate or contract price, to be paid when the contract is
completed. (Ord. 871, 2-17-1981)
8-2-13: PAYMENTS FOR EXTRA WORK:
No payment shall be made upon any work done by contract for any extra work not
specified therein, unless such extra work shall have been done by special order
of the board of local improvements. No officer of the corporation, or special
superintendent employed thereby, shall certify the account of any contractor
who has failed to comply with the terms of his contract, nor in any case in
advance of the progress of the work, and if he shall do so, he shall be liable
to the city for all loss that may arise therefrom. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 5,
Sec. 13)
CHAPTER 3
EXCAVATING PERMITS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Excavation Permit Required
8-3-2: Powers Of Superintendent Of Streets
8-3-3: Displacing Pavements
8-3-4: Application; Fee
8-3-5: Opening Parallel To Street (Rep. by Ord. 872, 2-17-1981)
8-3-6: Responsibility For Excavations
8-3-7: Reconstruction
8-3-8: Barriers, Lights
8-3-9: Construction Of Preceding Section
8-3-10: Damages
8-3-11: Duty Of Officers
8-3-12: Duty Of Gas Or Heating Companies
8-3-1: EXCAVATION PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall, without an express permit in writing, previously obtained in
each and every instance from the superintendent of streets, make any excavation
in any street or alley in the city for the purpose of laying water pipes, gas
pipes, conduits, erecting poles or constructing railway tracks, or for any
other purpose whatsoever, except such as are provided for elsewhere in this
code, under a penalty of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 6, Sec. 1)
8-3-2: POWERS OF SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS:
All shafts, cables, pipes, mains, conduits, tubes, wires or other transmitting
or conducting devices at any time laid or placed underneath the surface of any
street or alley in any manner forbidden by section
8-3-1 of this chapter, shall be promptly removed or cut out by the
superintendent of streets. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 6, Sec. 2)
8-3-3: DISPLACING PAVEMENTS:
It shall be unlawful to open or tear up any of the paved streets of the city
for any greater distance than two (2) blocks in extent at any one time, for the
purpose of laying railroad tracks, car tracks, sewers, telegraph or telephone
cables, or the repairs of the same, or other purposes other than laying down
new pavements. The pavement of the first block opened shall be temporarily
relaid and the debris removed before opening another block of the street in
which the work is being prosecuted. The superintendent of streets shall provide
the necessary rules governing the repairs in paved streets under this and other
chapters of this code, so that the pavements shall be absolutely replaced in as
good order as before being disturbed, within three (3) weeks after it is first
turned up; provided, that no person shall be permitted to excavate in or
disturb the surface of any street, alley or avenue which is improved by
pavement, for the purpose of laying any pipe, or main, or supply pipe or
lateral for the supply of gas. (Ord. 872, 2-17-1981)
8-3-4: APPLICATION; FEE:
Any person desiring a permit for any of the purposes mentioned in section
8-3-1 of this chapter shall make application therefor to the superintendent of
streets, upon a form to be provided by said superintendent for such purposes.
Such application shall state therein the purpose for which such excavation is
to be made and the date and time it is proposed to begin such work, and shall
be accompanied by a fee of one dollar ($1.00) for each such permit, where
excavation is to be made in dirt street, and five dollars ($5.00) for each such
permit when excavation is to be made in paved street. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art.
6, Sec. 4)
8-3-5: OPENING PARALLEL TO STREET:
(Rep. by Ord. 872, 2-17-1981)
8-3-6: RESPONSIBILITY FOR EXCAVATIONS:
Any person occupying any portion of any street or alley under any permit shall
save and keep the city free, clear and harmless from any and all loss or
liability on account of any accident or damages resulting from such occupation,
and shall fully remove all material, dirt and rubbish from the space so
occupied, and restore such street or alley to its original condition
immediately upon the expiration of the period named in said permit, and for any
failure so to do, such person shall be subject to a penalty of not less than
twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). The
penalty above prescribed shall not be construed to release such person from
liability for any damages sustained by the city, or by any person on account of
such occupation or excavation. (Ord. 872, 2-17-1981)
8-3-7: RECONSTRUCTION:
Whenever any part of any street, alley, sidewalk or other place in the city
shall be torn, dug or taken up for any purpose, the person tearing, digging or
taking up any earth, paving or planking shall immediately upon completion of
such purpose and as fast as possible during the accomplishment thereof, return
the earth, ram and pack down the same as fast as returned, to a firm and solid
bearing, and in a manner, if possible, that will entirely prevent any settling
of such earth, and shall also relay all paving, planking or graveling in a
skillful and permanent manner, and in every case to the satisfaction of the
said superintendent of streets of the city and under his direction, under a
penalty for any neglect or refusal so to do of not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00); and the
superintendent of streets is hereby authorized to adopt proper rules and
regulations for such relaying and replacing of such pavements and materials,
and he is hereby empowered to employ the necessary labor to do or assist in
doing the work of relaying and replacing such pavements and material, and to
collect the expense of such labor from the person receiving permission to tear
or dig or take up such earth, paving or planking; provided, that the expense of
labor so furnished shall not exceed that paid to the city for labor of like
character. (Ord. 872, 2-17-1981)
8-3-8: BARRIERS, LIGHTS:
It shall be the duty of any person or persons engaged in digging into any
street, alley or other public highway, in paving any street or alley, building
of any sewer or drain, or trench for water pipes or gas pipes in any of the
public alleys, avenues or other public places, under contract with the city, or
by virtue of any permission which may have been granted to them by the council,
or the superintendent of streets or city engineer, where such work, if left
exposed, would be dangerous to passengers, to erect a fence or railing at such
excavation or work in such a manner as to prevent danger to passengers who may
be traveling in streets, alleys, avenues or public places, and to continue the
said railing or fence until the work shall be completed or the obstruction or
danger removed. And it shall be the duty of such persons to place upon such
railing, fence, barrier or other obstruction at twilight in the evening,
suitable and sufficient light, and keep them burning through the night during
the performance of said work, under a penalty of not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for every such
neglect. (Ord. 872, 2-17-1981)
8-3-9: CONSTRUCTION OF PRECEDING SECTION:
The provisions of the preceding section shall apply to every person who shall
place building materials in any of the streets or avenues, or be engaged in
building any vault, or constructing any lateral drain from any cellar to any
public sewer, or who shall do or perform any work causing obstructions in any
of the public streets by virtue of any permit from any department or officer of
the city and also to all public officers engaged in performing any work in
behalf of the city whereby excavations or obstructions shall be made in the
public streets. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 6, Sec. 9)
8-3-10: DAMAGES:
In all cases where any person or persons shall perform any of the work
mentioned in the preceding sections, either under contract with the city or by
virtue of permission obtained by authority of the city, such person shall be
answerable for any and every damage which may be occasioned to persons, animals
or property by reason of carelessness in any manner connected with said work.
(R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 6, Sec. 10)
8-3-11: DUTY OF OFFICERS:
It shall be the duty of the superintendent of streets and police to see that
the requirements contained in this chapter in regard to the erection of fencing
or barriers and the placing of lights, and in regard to obtaining permits for
opening the streets, are in all cases complied with. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art.
6, Sec. 11)
8-3-12: DUTY OF GAS OR HEATING COMPANIES:
Every gas or heating plant company which has heretofore laid, or shall
hereafter lay down gas pipes or steam conductors in any street or alley in the
city, shall make and keep on file in the office of the clerk of the city, an
accurate map showing exact location of every line of pipe or conductors and
connections laid by them. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36, Art. 6, Sec. 12)
No such company shall open or encumber more of any street, alley or public
place at any one time than may be necessary to enable it to proceed with
advantage in the laying of pipes, nor shall said company permit any such
street, avenue or public place to remain open or encumbered for a longer period
than shall be necessary to execute the work for which the same shall have been
opened, or without putting up the necessary barriers and lights so as to
prevent the happening of any accident in consequence of such opening or
encumbrance of such street, alley, avenue or public place. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 36,
Art. 6, Sec. 13)
CHAPTER 4
STREETS, SIDEWALKS, PUBLIC GROUNDS
SECTION:
8-4-1: Leaving Excavation Unprotected
8-4-2: Removing Earth From Street
8-4-3: Fencing Streets
8-4-4: Removal Of Encroachments
8-4-5: Obstructing Streets
8-4-6: Blockade Of Streets By Vehicles
8-4-7: (Rep. by Ord. 643, 4-18-1978)
8-4-8: Debris And Waste In Streets
8-4-9: Casting Coal On Sidewalk
8-4-10: Altering Existing Curb Lines
8-4-11: Guard For Steps, Cellarways
8-4-12: Encumbering Outside Walk
8-4-13: Obstructing Sidewalks
8-4-14: Sales On Street
8-4-15: Construction Of Foregoing Section
8-4-16: Telephone And Telegraph Poles
8-4-17: Poles, Where Located
8-4-18: Wires
8-4-19: Sidewalk Construction By Special Taxation
8-4-20: Abutting Property Owners Responsible
8-4-21: Defective Sidewalks
8-4-22: Ordinance Specifications
8-4-23: Driving Against Curbstones (Rep. by Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-24: Contractor To Erect Guards
8-4-25: Driving Over Pavement Within Guards
8-4-26: Unlawful To Remove Guards
8-4-27: Wagon Boxes
8-4-28: Poles On Square
8-4-29: South Carolina Poplar
8-4-30: Names Of Streets
8-4-31: Penalty
8-4-32: Private Driveway Construction
8-4-33: Encroachments On Right Of Way
8-4-34: Solicitation On Public Ways
8-4-1: LEAVING EXCAVATION UNPROTECTED:
Any contractor for any public work, or any officer or other person, making any
excavation in any street, avenue, alley or sidewalk of the city, who shall
leave the same open and unprotected by lights or otherwise in the nighttime, so
as to endanger the safety of persons or animals passing thereby from falling
therein, shall be liable to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for every such neglect.
(Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-2: REMOVING EARTH FROM STREET:
Whoever shall, for any private purpose, dig, remove or carry away any earth,
gravel or sod from any street, avenue, alley or public ground, without the
express permission of the council, or of the committee on streets and alleys
thereof, shall forfeit and pay a penalty of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for
each and every load so removed and carried away; and any officer of the city
who shall use, sell or dispose of any earth, gravel or sod from any street,
avenue, alley or public ground, for his own private gain or benefit shall be
subject to a penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-3: FENCING STREETS:
No person shall make, or cause to be made, any enclosure, fence, bridge, arched
way or building of any kind extending upon, over or across any street, avenue,
alley or sidewalk within the city, under a penalty of not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense,
and a further fine of five dollars ($5.00) for every day that he shall allow
such enclosure, fence, bridge or building to remain, after being notified to
remove the same by the superintendent of streets or any police officer. (Ord.
873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-4: REMOVAL OF ENCROACHMENTS:
The owner, occupant or person in control of any building, fence or of any
structure or enclosure, already erected or built, extending into or encroaching
upon any street, avenue, alley or sidewalk within the city, who shall not
remove the same within thirty (30) days after being notified in writing to do
so by the superintendent of streets, or any police officer, shall be subject to
a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) and a further fine of five dollars ($5.00) for every day,
after the first conviction, that he shall fail or refuse to comply with such
notice. (Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-5: OBSTRUCTING STREETS:
Whoever shall place, throw or leave, or shall cause to be placed, thrown or
left, any obstruction or encumbrance in or upon any street, avenue, alley or
public ground in the city, except as authorized by ordinance, shall be liable
to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00), and to a further fine of five dollars ($5.00) for
every additional day that he shall fail to remove such obstruction or
encumbrance, after being notified to do so by the superintendent of streets or
any policeman. (Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-6: BLOCKADE OF STREETS BY VEHICLES:
When any street, avenue or alley shall be obstructed by motor vehicles, animals
or persons, any police officer of the city, may give such orders and directions
as shall be deemed necessary to abate the obstruction; and whoever shall refuse
or neglect to obey such orders or directions shall be subject to a penalty of
twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-7: (Rep. by Ord. 643, 4-18-1978)
8-4-8: DEBRIS AND WASTE IN STREETS:
No person shall throw, place or leave, or cause or permit to be thrown, placed,
or left, any ashes, dirt, filth, rubbish or yard waste (including, but not
limited to, grass clippings and leaves) upon any street, avenue, alley or
sidewalk of the city, in front of or adjoining any premises or buildings owned,
occupied or controlled by him, under a penalty of not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense,
and a further penalty of five dollars ($5.00) for each additional day that such
person shall permit such ashes, dirt, filth, rubbish and yard waste (including,
but not limited to, grass clippings and leaves) to remain, after notice to
remove same from the superintendent of streets, or any policeman or code
enforcement officer; except that cinders may be deposited upon the paved
streets of the city, by and with the consent of the committee on streets and
alleys and crossings, and under the supervision of the superintendent of
streets. (Ord. 3017, 6-4-2013)
8-4-9: CASTING COAL ON SIDEWALK:
Whoever shall throw, place or leave any live coals or fire, or make or kindle
any fire upon any sidewalk, alley or street crossing, or causes, suffers,
permits or directs the same to be done, shall be subject to a penalty of not
less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each offense, and shall also be liable for all damages or injury
caused thereby. The cost of repairing any such damage or injury may be
recovered in a separate suit in the name of the city. (Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-10: ALTERING EXISTING CURB LINES:
No person shall break, lower or alter the existing curb line around any street
intersection corner in the city. Whoever shall violate the provisions of this
section shall be fined in a sum not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 873, 2-17-
1981)
8-4-11: GUARD FOR STEPS, CELLARWAYS:
No steps or platform shall extend into or upon any sidewalk or alley in the
city more than three feet (3'); and all stairs or steps encroaching upon any
sidewalk or alley and leading to the upper story of any building shall be
securely fastened to the wall of such building and supported without posts or
pillars. No open cellar or basement way shall be permitted to extend into any
sidewalk more than three feet (3'), and in all cases shall be well protected
with a substantial iron railing with a gate at the entrance around same; nor
shall any closed cellar or basement way extend into or upon any sidewalk more
than five feet (5'), nor into any alley more than four feet (4'); nor shall the
door or grating of any such closed cellar or basement way extend above the
grade of the sidewalk, nor exceeding one inch (1") above the grade of the
alley; nor shall the hinges, lock or other fastenings thereof be placed on the
upper side of the same so as to project above the door, unless within two and
one-half feet (21/2') of the building; and all cellar windows or coal holes in
any sidewalk or alley shall be set or placed even with the grade of such
sidewalk or alley, and be well secured with iron or other suitable gratings.
Whoever shall violate or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this
section shall be subject to a penalty of not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and to
a further penalty of five dollars ($5.00) for each day he shall fail or refuse
to comply herewith, after notice to do so by the mayor or superintendent of
streets. (Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-12: ENCUMBERING OUTSIDE WALK:
No person shall encumber or obstruct more than three feet (3') of the outer
edge of any sidewalk with any goods, merchandise, fuel or other articles he may
be receiving or delivering, nor shall he permit the same to remain upon any
sidewalk longer than may be necessary in the diligent removal thereof, nor in
any case to exceed six (6) hours, under a penalty of three dollars ($3.00) for
each offense, and a further penalty of one dollar ($1.00) for every two (2)
hours he shall permit any such encumbrance or obstruction to remain after being
notified to remove the same by the superintendent of streets or any member of
the police force. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 12)
8-4-13: OBSTRUCTING SIDEWALKS:
No person shall encumber or obstruct any part of any sidewalk, or space within
the curb line, with signboards or advertising boards, boxes, barrels or other
articles, nor with shelves or other structures for the display of any goods,
merchandise, fruit, vegetables, groceries or other articles, under a penalty of
three dollars ($3.00) for each offense, and a further penalty of one dollar
($1.00) for every two (2) hours he shall permit any such encumbrance or
obstruction to remain after being notified to remove the same by the
superintendent of streets, or any member of the police force; provided, that
barber poles, properly fastened and erected at the edge of the sidewalk, and
sign or advertising boards, properly fastened to a building, may remain. (R.O.
1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 13)
8-4-14: SALES ON STREET:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, place or maintain in or upon any
street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in the city any fruit stand,
lunch stand, lunch wagon, popcorn stand or any table, box, bin, rack, showcase,
platform, vehicle or any other arrangement or structure for the sale of goods,
wares or merchandise, or for the pursuit of any occupation whatsoever, unless a
permit for the same shall be obtained from the council. And no permit shall be
issued by the council, upon objection of the occupant of the premises in front
of which it is proposed to locate under such permission; provided that when any
person is refused permission under the foregoing and has obtained a license
from the proper authorities, he may surrender said license to the officer
issuing the same, and receive back the fee paid for the same.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to
a penalty of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than fifty dollars
($50.00) for each offense. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 14)
8-4-15: CONSTRUCTION OF FOREGOING SECTION:
The foregoing section shall not be so construed as to apply to any person or
persons coming into the city from the country with any produce for market
raised by themselves, or to any person selling vegetables, berries, fruit, milk
or other farm produce of their own production; nor shall the same be so
construed as to make it a penal offense to peddle newspapers, nor to apply to
judicial sales, nor to any person acting under license from the city; provided,
that farmers or others selling under the provisions of this section shall not
occupy a stand upon any sidewalk, alley or crossing, nor within a space of ten
feet (10') of any such sidewalk or crossing upon any street or public square,
nor shall they allow their stand, wagon or other vehicle from which they may be
selling to remain in front of any person's place of business without the
consent of the occupant of such place of business, nor so as to obstruct the
convenient travel of the street. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 15)
8-4-16: TELEPHONE AND TELEGRAPH POLES:
No person shall set or cause to be set any telegraph, telephone, electric light
or other poles upon any street or alley within the city, or string or hang any
wire along or across any street or alley, unless authorized so to do by the
council, under a penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-17: POLES, WHERE LOCATED:
All electric light, telegraph and telephone poles now in any street of the
city, or which shall hereafter be placed on any alley or street, shall be
located and placed within the curb lines on the sidewalk side thereof, which
are now or may hereafter be established; and poles shall be placed as near as
may be in a line in such streets. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 17)
8-4-18: WIRES:
All wires suspended from said poles shall be at least eighteen feet (18') high
above the level of the street grade, and said poles shall be neatly smoothed
and in a fit condition to be painted. All high tension wires shall, so far as
practicable, be kept upon opposite sides of the streets from telephone and
telegraph wires. (Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-19: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION BY SPECIAL TAXATION:
All new sidewalks and condemned sidewalks shall be constructed by special
taxation, levied upon abutting landowners, and it shall be the duty of said
landowner, whenever the same becomes defective or needs repairs, to repair the
same without notice and keep the same in repair, using the same kind of
material of which the sidewalk is constructed. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec.
19)
8-4-20: ABUTTING PROPERTY OWNERS RESPONSIBLE:
Whenever any sidewalk in the city shall need repairs, the abutting landowner
shall make the needed repairs; and if any owner shall fail to repair the same,
the superintendent of streets shall give such owner three (3) days' notice to
repair, and shall file a copy of said notice with the clerk; and upon such
owner failing or refusing to repair the same, an ordinance shall be passed to
repair, renew or condemn the same and shall require the same to be constructed
by special taxation; which ordinance shall be passed according to law, for such
purpose. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 20)
8-4-21: DEFECTIVE SIDEWALKS:
Whenever any sidewalk shall not be repairable, an ordinance shall be passed
condemning such defective sidewalk and requiring the same to be rebuilt by
special taxation; and new sidewalks shall be built by like taxation. (R.O.
1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 21)
8-4-22: ORDINANCE SPECIFICATIONS:
All ordinances shall provide and specify the material which shall be used in
such construction or repair, and the width and location of the same, and that
the owners of abutting lands shall have the time allowed by law to build and
construct the same, and in all other respects said ordinance shall conform to
law. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 22)
8-4-23: DRIVING AGAINST CURBSTONES:
(Rep. by Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-24: CONTRACTOR TO ERECT GUARDS:
When any street, alley or other public place in the city shall hereafter be
paved or otherwise improved, it shall be the duty of the contractor or
contractors who have charge of said work to cause to be placed in said street,
alley or public place at the intersection of all cross streets, proper and
sufficient guards to prevent automobiles, machinery or vehicles of all kinds
and descriptions, and animals of all kinds and descriptions, from entering in
and upon such streets so being paved or otherwise improved, for a distance of
at least one block from that part of the said improvement that has been lastly
constructed. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 24)
8-4-25: DRIVING OVER PAVEMENT WITHIN GUARDS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride, drive or in any manner propel any
kind of vehicle or piece of machinery, or to lead, ride or drive any horse,
mule or cow over, along or upon that portion of any street, alley or other
public place in the city so being paved or otherwise improved that is within
the guards or obstructions placed upon such street, alley or public place by
the party in charge of such pavement or improvement as provided in the
preceding section. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 25)
8-4-26: UNLAWFUL TO REMOVE GUARDS:
It shall be unlawful for any person other than those engaged in the
construction of said pavement or improvement to remove or destroy any such
guards or obstructions placed upon any street, alley or public place that is
being paved or improved. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 26)
8-4-27: WAGON BOXES:
   (A)   Wagon Boxes To Be Tight: Any person who shall be engaged in drawing
upon any street, crushed stone, sand, gravel, sawdust, ashes, cinders, lime,
tan bark, shavings, wastepaper, ice, mortar, rubbish, manure or other loose
material likely to sift, fall or be blown upon the streets, shall convey and
carry the same in tight wagon boxes, and in case the same fall or be scattered
in any street, such person shall cause it to be forthwith removed. Any person
violating any provision of this section shall be fined not less than twenty
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense.
   (B)   Wagon Boxes, Overloaded: Any person causing any cart, wagon or other
vehicle to be loaded and heaped up so that the contents or any part thereof
shall be scattered in any street, or other place in the city, shall be fined
not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 873, 2-17-1981)
8-4-28: POLES ON SQUARE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain upon the public
square, or upon any of the streets radiating from the public square, in the
city, any poles for the purpose of conducting telegraph, telephone or electric
light wires. Any person violating the terms of this section shall be fined,
upon conviction, not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and each day's neglect to move same
after notice to do so shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 873, 2-17-
1981)
8-4-29: SOUTH CAROLINA POPLAR:
   (A)   South Carolina Poplar Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person
to plant or cause to be planted in any of the public streets of the city, in
the parts of such streets commonly called parkings, any tree or trees of the
variety commonly known as South Carolina poplar. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1,
Sec. 30)
   (B)   Distance From Sidewalk: It shall be unlawful for any person to plant
or cause to be planted in or upon any lawn or other private premises within the
corporate limits of the city, any tree or trees of the variety commonly known
as South Carolina poplars, within a distance of fifty feet (50') from any
sidewalk or sidewalk line; and it further shall be unlawful for any person to
plant or cause to be planted in or upon any lawn or other private premises,
within the city, or in any of the public streets of the city, in the parts of
such streets commonly called parkings, any tree or trees of any variety
whatsoever within a distance of four feet (4') from any sidewalk or sidewalk
line. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 41, Art. 1, Sec. 31)
8-4-30: NAMES OF STREETS:
   (A)   Plan Of Naming Streets And Avenues: Except where the city council
finds that deviations are appropriate and beneficial to the city of Canton, the
streets of the city shall be named in accordance with the following plan: All
streets running north and south parallel to Main Street shall be known as
"avenues"; all streets east of Main Street shall be numbered First Avenue,
Second Avenue, etc.; all streets west of Main Street shall be lettered Avenue
A, Avenue B, etc.; all streets running east and west parallel to Elm Street
shall be known as "streets", and shall be named and known after some kind of
wood; all short streets running east and west shall be known as "places"; all
short streets running north and south shall be known as "courts".
   (B)   Names Of Certain Streets Designated: Except where the city council
finds that deviations are appropriate and beneficial to the city of Canton, all
short streets running east and west shall be known as "places" and all short
streets running north and south shall be known as "courts" and shall bear such
names as hereinbefore or as hereafter provided for by ordinances of the city.
(Ord. 624, 1-3-1978)
8-4-31: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, or refusing or
neglecting to conform and comply therewith, shall, where no specific penalty is
provided, be subject to a penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 873, 2-17-
1981)
8-4-32: PRIVATE DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to make or construct a private driveway for
the use of vehicular traffic into any public street in the city of Canton,
Illinois, without first having procured a permit therefor from the city
engineer of said city.
Any person desiring to make or construct such a private driveway shall pay a
twenty five dollar ($25.00) application fee to the building official who shall
forward the fee to the city clerk. Should the permit be denied, the permit fee
shall not be refunded to the applicant. The applicant shall proceed in such
private driveway construction only when a permit therefor has been received in
writing from said building official. (Ord. 1771, 9-16-2003)
The city engineer of this city shall either issue or deny the permit, herein
contemplated, within ten (10) days of the application therefor, herein
contemplated.
Any person who undertakes to make or construct such a private driveway, as
herein contemplated, without first having procured the written permit therefor,
herein contemplated, shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and that each day such a
private driveway subsists without such a permit therefor shall be deemed a
separate offense which shall be punished by fine of not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 553, 8-3-1976)
8-4-33: ENCROACHMENTS ON RIGHT OF WAY:
   (A)   Definitions:
CONSTRUCTION EASEMENT AREA: The area lying between the project right of way
limits and the platted street limits within which the city, by concurrence in
the establishment of the project right of way lines, will permit the state to
enter to perform all necessary construction operations.
ENCROACH- MENT: Any building, fence, sign or any other structure or object of
any kind (with the exception of utilities and public road signs), which is
placed, located or maintained in, on, under or over any portion of the project
right of way or the roadway right of way where no project right of way line has
been established.
PERMISSIBLE ENCROACHMENT: Any existing awning, marquee or sign advertising
activity on the property or similar overhanging structure supported from a
building immediately adjacent to the limits of the platted street where there
is a sidewalk extending to the building line and which does not impair the free
and safe flow of traffic on the highway, the permissive retention of
overhanging signs is not to be construed as being applicable to those signs
supported from poles constructed outside the project right of way line and not
confined by adjacent buildings.
PROJECT RIGHT OF WAY: Areas within the project right of way lines established
jointly by the city and state which will be free of encroachments except as
herein defined.
ROADWAY RIGHT OF WAY: Areas existing or acquired by dedication or by fee simple
for highway purposes; also, the areas acquired by temporary easement during the
time the easement is in effect.
   (B)   Unlawful To Erect And Retain: It shall be unlawful for any person,
firm or corporation to erect or cause to be erected, to retain or cause to be
retained, any "encroachment" as defined in this section, within the limits of
the project right of way or roadway right of way where no project right of way
lines have been established.
   (C)   Addition To Regulations: This section is intended to and shall be in
addition to all other ordinances, rules and regulations concerning
encroachments and shall not be construed as repealing or rescinding any other
ordinance or part of any ordinance unless in direct conflict therewith. (Ord.
899, 10-20-1981)
8-4-34: SOLICITATION ON PUBLIC WAYS:
   (A)   Contributions:
      1.   Registration Required: No person shall stand on a public way,
including a state highway or a city street, for the purposes of soliciting
contributions from the occupant of any vehicle within the corporate limits of
the city unless said individual or individuals shall have first registered with
the city on the registration form provided by the city. Registration with the
city must be requested a minimum of fourteen (14) days prior to the planned
commencement of solicitation.
      2.   Permitted Locations: Solicitation on the state highways or public
streets within the city shall be allowed only at intersections where all
traffic is required to come to a full stop.
      3.   Safety Vest Required: All solicitors must wear a highly visible,
orange or green safety vest at all times when in the public way.
      4.   Minimum Age; Solicitors Only: All solicitors must be at least
sixteen (16) years of age. No one shall be in the public way except solicitors.
      5.   Hours Of Solicitation: All solicitation on public ways shall occur
between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M.
      6.   Soliciting Restricted: The soliciting agency or individual shall be
restricted and limited to solicitation on the public way to no more than two
(2) dates in any given calendar month and no more than four (4) days during any
calendar year.
      7.   Purpose Posted: The purpose of the fundraising event must be posted
to identify the soliciting organization. Examples: readable signs on the
collection container, identification on the safety vests of the solicitors,
etc.
      8.   Additional Requirements For Solicitation On State Highways:
         (a)   The soliciting agency or individual shall further be registered
with the attorney general as a charitable organization as provided by "an act
to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for charitable purposes,
providing for violations thereof, and making an appropriation therefore",
approved July 26, 1963, as amended; and
         (b)   The soliciting agency or individual shall further be engaged in
a statewide fundraising activity; and
         (c)   The soliciting agency or individual shall further be liable for
any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is
causally connected to any act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent.
   (B)   Penalty: Violations of this section shall be governed by title 1,
chapter 27, "General Penalty", of this code and the fee schedule that is
adopted by city council from time to time. Any person who is found to be in
violation of this chapter shall be removed from soliciting and at the city's
determination, may be suspended from being allowed to solicit on public ways
for one year. (Ord. 4049, 11-1-2016)
CHAPTER 5
TREES AND SHRUBS
SECTION:
8-5-1: Definitions
8-5-2: Permit Required
8-5-3: Planting Near Intersections
8-5-4: Trimming
8-5-5: Defacing
8-5-6: Trees Permitted
8-5-7: Exclusion
8-5-8: Penalty
8-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
Wherever in this chapter the following words or terms are used, they shall have
ascribed to them the following meanings:
BUSH OR SHRUB: A woody perennial plant smaller than a tree with close branches
arising from or near the ground.
TERRACE: The land lying between a street or roadway and sidewalk.
TREE: A perennial plant having a self-supporting main stem or trunk which
develops woody branches some distance from the ground, and grows to a
considerable height and size. (Ord. 143, 7-20-1965)
8-5-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall plant or remove any tree, bush or shrub on any terrace or land
within ten feet (10') of any sidewalk, street or roadway within the corporate
limits of Canton, without first having obtained a permit.
Any person desiring to plant or remove on any of the places above set forth
shall apply to the office of the clerk. The clerk shall furnish such person
with an application requesting the following information:
   (A)   Name and address of applicant.
   (B)   Species of tree, plant or shrub to be planted or removed.
   (C)   Sketch showing location of tree, bush or shrub to be removed or
planted, with measurements of adjacent sidewalks, streets and roadways, and
street intersections.
   (D)   Such other information as the committee on streets and alleys deem
reasonable.
The clerk shall furnish the applicant with a list of the species of trees that
may be planted.
The applicant shall return his application to the clerk who shall refer the
same to the superintendent of streets, who, if he finds the application
complies with this chapter shall then approve the same. The clerk shall then
issue a permit to the applicant who then may plant or remove said tree, plant
or shrub in compliance with the permit. The superintendent shall inspect the
premises where said tree, plant or shrub has been planted or removed to see if
the applicant has complied with the terms of the permit.
In granting said permit and in his inspection, the superintendent of streets
shall see that the provisions of this chapter are reasonably complied with and
may refer any application or inspection to the committee on streets and alleys
for its opinion. (Ord. 143, 7-20-1965)
8-5-3: PLANTING NEAR INTERSECTIONS:
The planting of any tree, bush or shrub within two feet (2') of any street,
roadway or sidewalk or within twenty five feet (25') of any street intersection
within the corporate limits of the city is prohibited. (Ord. 143, 7-20-1965)
8-5-4: TRIMMING:
All trees, shrubs and trees now in existence or which may hereafter be planted
on any premises within the corporate limits of the city bordering a public
street or roadway shall be trimmed or cut so that the limbs, stems and branches
shall not interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic and no stem, limb or
branch shall be less than eight feet (8') above any sidewalk and not less than
twelve feet (12') above any street or roadway. (Ord. 143, 7-20-1965)
8-5-5: DEFACING:
No person shall injure, mar or deface any tree, bush, shrub or flower on a
public street, terrace, city park or city property. (Ord. 143, 7-20-1965)
8-5-6: TREES PERMITTED:
Permits shall be issued for the planting of the following species of trees
only: skyline locust; shade master locust; sunburst locust; crimson king maple;
Schwedleri maple; European ash; oak leaf ash; golden raintree; red bud (Judas
tree); flowering crabapple (no fruit); American hornbeam; Moraine ash; autumn
higan cherry; Fugenzo oriental cherry; paperback maple; sorrel tree (sourwood);
sweetgum; scarlet maple; sugar maple; green ash; flowering crab; Kwanzan
cherry; northern red oak; amur cork; little leaf linden; ginkgo; crimson king;
Norway maple; mountain ash; Bradford pear; Marshal, seedless ash; flowering
crab; pink crab; Vanguard crab; and Zumi crab. (Ord. 541, 4-6-1976)
8-5-7: EXCLUSION:
Due to the fact that the city has no jurisdiction of the terraces abutting
state bond issue routes numbered 9 and 78, the provisions of this chapter shall
not apply to the premises abutting said routes. (Ord. 143, 7-20-1965)
8-5-8: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be punished by a fine not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (1975 Code)
CHAPTER 6
GRADES
SECTION:
8-6-1: Datum Plane Established
8-6-2: Sidewalks To Conform
8-6-3: New Sidewalks To Conform
8-6-4: City Engineer To Give Grade
8-6-5: Railroad Tracks To Conform
8-6-6: Bridges, Culverts, Crossings To Conform
8-6-1: DATUM PLANE ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a base or datum plane of reference to which all
city levels, and all permanent grade points, hereinafter established, shall
refer. Said base or datum plane shall be taken as a reference plane, and is
hereby established at one hundred feet (100') below the top of a bronze pin set
in a concrete post in the southwest quarter of Jones park in the public square
in the city, and being approximately at a point forty four feet (44') east of
the outer face of the curb on the west side of said Jones park, and two hundred
four and seven- tenths feet (204.7') north of the outer face of the curb on the
south end of Jones park. The permanent grades of all streets and alleys in the
city, hereinafter fixed, shall refer to said base or datum plane. The U.S.
geological survey elevation is equal to five hundred sixty two and six-tenths
feet (562.6') plus the city data. (Ord. 875, 3-17-1981)
8-6-2: SIDEWALKS TO CONFORM:
No person shall construct or lay, or cause to be constructed or laid, any
sidewalk where no grade has been established without having first obtained a
grade therefor from the city engineer, or contrary to any grade given by said
engineer, nor shall construct, or cause to be constructed, any sidewalk
contrary to any grade which may have been, or may be hereafter, established by
the council, under a penalty of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each offense,
and a further penalty of five dollars ($5.00) for each day that he shall fail
to make said sidewalk conform to the proper grade, after five (5) days' notice
so to do by the superintendent of streets. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 22, Sec. 2)
8-6-3: NEW SIDEWALKS TO CONFORM:
All new sidewalks that may be rebuilt, shall be built on and made to conform to
the grade which shall be established by the city engineer, and a record of the
sidewalk grade when established, shall be kept in a book provided for that
purpose, and permanent stone landmarks set below the frost line to keep the
grade line as established in a condition to be ascertained for the purpose of
public improvements in the city. Any person violating any of the provisions of
this section shall be subject to a penalty of not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each and every
offense. (Ord. 875, 3-17-1981)
8-6-4: CITY ENGINEER TO GIVE GRADE:
When the city shall require a new sidewalk to be built and constructed, or
shall condemn an old sidewalk and require the construction of a new sidewalk,
before the same shall be required to be constructed, the city shall establish
the grade, and shall also make the grade ready for the construction of said
sidewalk, and put the same in proper condition for the laying of the sidewalk
as may be required, which said grading shall be done and prepared by general
taxation. It shall be the duty of the city engineer to establish such grade,
and the grades herein required to be prepared shall be done by and under the
supervision of the superintendent of streets of the city. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 22,
Sec. 4)
8-6-5: RAILROAD TRACKS TO CONFORM:
It shall be the duty of all railroad companies or corporations, or the owners
or proprietors of all railroad tracks, whose tracks now or hereafter may enter
or pass through the city, or whose tracks are located upon, or may hereafter be
located upon, any streets or alleys within the city, to raise or lower their
respective tracks to conform to any grade which is or may be established by the
city, or any street upon or through which said railroad tracks may run, and
where such tracks run lengthwise of any street, to keep the same not to exceed
one inch (1") above the surface of such street, and so that such streets may be
conveniently crossed at any place on such street. Any railroad or railway
company or corporation failing, neglecting or refusing to comply with the
provisions of this section, after five (5) days' notice so to do in writing by
the superintendent of streets, shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense; and the
recovery of one fine shall be no bar to future prosecution for a like failure
or neglect. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 22, Sec. 5)
8-6-6: BRIDGES, CULVERTS, CROSSINGS TO CONFORM:
All bridges, culverts and street crossings hereafter constructed upon any
street within the city shall be so constructed as to conform, as nearly as
possible, to the established grade of the street upon which said bridges,
culverts or crossings shall be located. (R.O. 1959, Ch. 22, Sec. 6)
CHAPTER 7
CEMETERIES, ADMINISTRATION
SECTION:
8-7-1: Administration Of Cemetery; Accounting
8-7-2: Duties; Fees
8-7-3: Perpetual Care
8-7-4: Deeds
8-7-1: ADMINISTRATION OF CEMETERY; ACCOUNTING:
   (A)   Administration: The superintendent of buildings and grounds shall have
the care, charge, management, and control of any cemetery under the supervision
of the city. Employees of cemetery are employees of the city of Canton and
shall be under the supervision of the superintendent of buildings and grounds;
provided, however, that such care, management, and control shall be under the
supervision of the city council.
   (B)   Appraisal Of Lots: The superintendent of buildings and grounds, or his
designee, shall appraise the lots which remain unsold in the cemeteries, and
shall, from time to time, when deemed expedient reappraise such lots as remain
unsold.
   (C)   Manner Of Expending Receipts: All receipts on account of said
cemeteries shall be in custody of the city treasurer whether the same be by
appropriation by the council, donations, sale of lots or by contributions to
the perpetual care fund as hereinafter provided for said receipts arising from
the sale of lots, from donations, or from appropriations by the council and
shall be exclusively expended and applied under the direction and control of
the council in preserving, protecting, ornamenting, improving and laying out
the grounds of said cemeteries, and the avenues and walks therein. But the city
