   (J)   Name Of Subdivision: The name of the subdivision and name or number of
the larger subdivision or tract of which the tract now subdivided forms a part.
   (K)   Adjoining Subdivisions, Lakes, Etc.: The names and locations of
adjoining subdivisions and locations and ownership of adjoining unsubdivided
property. Where provisions are made for access to an adjoining lake or stream,
a sketch illustrating such access shall be submitted.
   (L)   Names Of Owners, Etc.: The names and addresses of the owner or owners
of record, the subdivider and the registered Illinois land surveyor or
engineer.
   (M)   Legend: North point, scale, date and title.
   (N)   Statement Concerning Lot Area: At the subdivider's discretion, a
statement that any lot transferred will have a minimum width and area
substantially the same as those shown on the plat, and that only one principal
building will be permitted on any such lot.
   (O)   Affidavits And Certificates: Affidavits and certificates by the
surveyor to the effect that he has fully complied with the requirements of this
title and the subdivision laws of the state of Illinois in surveying, dividing
and mapping the land; that the plat is a correct representation of all the
exterior boundaries of the land surveyed and the subdivision of it; and that
the plat represents a survey made by him and that all monuments indicated
thereon actually exist and their location, size and material is correctly
shown.
   (P)   Owner's Certificate: A certificate by the owner of the land in
substantially the following form: "As owner I hereby certify that I caused the
land described on this plat to be surveyed, divided, mapped and dedicated as
represented on the plat". This certificate shall be executed as a conveyance.
   (Q)   Certificate Of Taxes Paid: A certificate issued by the authorized city
and county officials to the effect that there are no unpaid taxes or unpaid
special assessments on any of the lands included in the plats. (Ord. 726, 7-17-
1979)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 10 of this code.
CHAPTER 7
MODIFICATIONS
SECTION:
11-7-1: Modification Undue Hardship
11-7-2: Planned Unit Development
11-7-1: MODIFICATION UNDUE HARDSHIP:
In any case where the subdivider can show that by reason of exceptional
topographic or other physical conditions, strict compliance with any
requirement of this title would cause undue hardship, the platting authority
may relax such requirements to the extent deemed just and proper, so as to
relieve such difficulty or hardship; provided that such relief may be granted
without detriment to the public good and without impairing the intent and
purpose of these regulations or the desirable general development of the
neighborhood and the community in accordance with the comprehensive plan and
the zoning title 1 . Any modification thus granted shall be stated in writing
and filed with the records of the subdivision and in the office of the joint
planning and zoning commission setting forth the reasons which, in the opinion
of the platting authority, justified the modification. (Ord. 726, 7-17-1979;
amd. Ord. 3041, 12-3-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 10 of this code.
11-7-2: PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT:
The standards and requirements of these regulations may be modified by the
joint planning and zoning commission in the case of a plan and program for a
complete community or a planned unit development which, in the judgment of the
joint planning and zoning commission, will provide adequate public spaces and
improvements for traffic circulation, recreation, light, air and the service
needs of the area when fully developed and populated 1 .
Such plan and program shall include such legal provisions as will assure
achievement of the plan as finally approved by the joint planning and zoning
commission. (Ord. 726, 7-17-1979; amd. Ord. 3041, 12-3-2013)
 
Notes
1 2. See title 10, chapter 13 of this code for planned unit developments.

11-8-3: Effective Date

invalidity of any section or provision hereof shall not affect the validity of
other provisions hereof. (Ord. 726, 7-17-1979)
11-8-3: EFFECTIVE DATE:

approval and publication as provided by law. (Ord. 726, 7-17-1979)
CHAPTER 9
PRINCIPLES OF DESIGN AND MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
11-9-1: Principles And Requirements
11-9-1: PRINCIPLES AND REQUIREMENTS:
In laying out a subdivision, the subdivider shall comply with the following
principles and requirements:
   (A)   General:
      1.   The subdivision layout shall conform to the official major street
plan:
         (a)   Whenever a tract to be subdivided embraces any part of a major
or collector street, so designated on said plan, such part of such public way
shall be platted by the subdivider at the location and of the width indicated
on the plan. Section and quarter section line streets should be considered for
collector streets.
         (b)   Where a proposed park, playground, school site or other public
area shown on the park and playground plan or other part of the master plan is
located in whole or in part within the proposed subdivision, such proposed
public ground or park shall be dedicated to the city, park district and board
of education of the county. Where considered desirable by the developer and
appropriate by the platting authority, open spaces constituting a reasonable
proportion of the gross acreage of the subdivision, suitably located and of
adequate size for parks, playgrounds or other recreational purposes for local
or neighborhood use, shall be provided for in the proposed subdivision, and, if
not dedicated to the city, park district, board of education or county, as the
case may be, may be reserved for the common use of all property owners in the
proposed subdivision by covenant or deed restriction.
   (B)   The Street And Block Layout:
      1.   The street layout of the subdivision shall be in general conformity
with a plan for the most advantageous development of adjoining areas and the
entire neighborhood.
         (a)   Where appropriate to the design, proposed streets shall be
continuous and in alignment with existing, planned or platted streets with
which they are to connect.
         (b)   Proposed streets shall be extended to the boundary lines of the
tract to be subdivided, unless prevented by topography or other physical
conditions or unless, in the opinion of the platting authority, such extension
is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the
subdivision with the existing layout or the most advantageous future
development of the adjacent tracts. Dead end streets of reasonable length
(normally not over 500 feet) will be approved where necessary by topography.
         (c)   Proposed streets shall intersect one another as nearly at right
angles as topography and other limiting factors of good design permit.
         (d)   Wherever there exists adjacent to the tract to be subdivided an
existing township or county roadway, the subdivider shall be responsible for
the construction of said roadway to the subdivision standards for that half of
the roadway abutting the property to be subdivided. In lieu of the above
construction, an escrow in the amount of the construction may be accepted by
the city council.
         (e)   Alleys shall be platted in all business districts. To provide
safe access to residential lots fronting on major streets, alleys shall be
platted in the rear of such lots or service drives in front thereof.
         (f)   Easements for utilities shall be provided in the rear of all
residential lots except where alleys are provided for under subsection (B)1(e)
of this section. Easements for utilities also shall be provided alongside lot
lines where required.
         (g)   Lands abutting major streets shall be platted with the view of
making the lots, if for residential use, desirable for such use by cushioning
the impact of heavy traffic on such trafficways and with the view also of
minimizing interference with traffic on such trafficways as well as the
accident hazard. This may be accomplished in several ways:
            (1)   By platting the lots abutting such trafficways at very
generous depth, with setbacks or front yards at least ten feet (10') greater or
deeper than otherwise required; and providing vehicular access to them by means
of either alleys or service drives in the rear, or frontage access roads next
to the highways, connected therewith at frequent intervals.
            (2)   By not fronting the lots on the highway but on a minor street
paralleling the highway at a distance of a generous lot depth. Private
driveways in this case shall connect with such minor streets.
            (3)   By a collector street platted more or less parallel with a
highway, six hundred (600) to one thousand feet (1,000') distance therefrom,
from which loop streets or dead end streets would extend toward the highway,
the ends of which provide access to the lots abutting the highway to their
rear.
The foregoing, or other methods for accomplishing the purposes in question must
necessarily be done in consideration of the topography and other physical
conditions, the character of existing and contemplated developments and other
pertinent factors that apply in each case.
      2.   Blocks shall have sufficient width to provide for two (2) tiers of
lots of appropriate depth.
         (a)   The length of blocks shall be such as, in the opinion of the
platting authority, are appropriate for the locality and the type of
development contemplated, but shall not exceed one thousand five hundred feet
(1,500') where the average size of lots does not exceed two (2) acres in the
area.
         (b)   In any block over nine hundred feet (900') in length, the
platting authority may require that a crosswalk or pedestrianway not less than
ten feet (10') wide be provided near the center and entirely across such block.
         (c)   The number of intersecting streets along major streets shall be
held to a minimum. Wherever practicable, blocks along such trafficways shall
not be less than one thousand two hundred feet (1,200') in length.
   (C)   Minimum Right Of Way Widths Of Streets, Alleys And Easements For
Utilities:
      1.   Major streets shall be no less than one hundred feet (100') with
median and not less than eighty feet (80') where there is to be no median.
      2.   Collector streets shall not be less than sixty feet (60') wide.
      3.   Local streets shall not be less than sixty feet (60') wide in all
residential districts.
      4.   All dead end streets shall terminate in a circular turnaround having
a minimum right of way diameter of one hundred feet (100').
      5.   Alleys shall not be less than twenty feet (20').
      6.   Where easements are required for utilities, they shall be centered
on rear or side lot lines and their widths shall not be less than ten feet
(10') where electric and telephone lines are to be accommodated and ordinarily
not more than twenty feet (20') if, in addition, sewer, water or gas lines are
to be accommodated.
      7.   Easements for open drainage channels shall be thirty feet (30') wide
centered on the channel. Easements for enclosed storm drains shall be no less
than ten feet (10') or five (5) times the diameter of the storm drain.
   (D)   Minimum Pavement Widths:
      1.   Minimum pavement width for local streets shall be thirty feet (30')
between faces of curbs in all residential districts and thirty feet (30')
between faces of curbs on all other local streets and thirty six feet (36')
between faces of curbs on collector streets. The pavement widths for major
streets shall be determined by the city in each case. The pavement of a turning
circle at the end of a dead end street shall have a minimum outside diameter of
eighty feet (80').
   (E)   Street Grades, Curves And Sight Distances:
      1.   The grades of streets shall not exceed the following except where
topography necessitates:
         (a)   Mayor streets: Four percent (4%),
         (b)   Collector streets, local streets, services drives and alleys:
Seven percent (7%),
         (c)   Pedestrianways or crosswalks: Twelve percent (12%).
Unless steps of an acceptable design are to be constructed.
      2.   All changes in street grades in excess of one percent (1%) shall be
connected by vertical curves of a minimum length equal to fifteen (15) times
the algebraic difference in the rate of grade for major streets and one-half
(1/2) of this minimum for all other streets.
      3.   The radii of curvature on the center line shall not be less than the
following:
         (a)   Major streets: Four hundred feet (400'),
         (b)   Collector streets: Three hundred feet (300'),
         (c)   Local streets and service drives: One hundred feet (100').
   (F)   Intersections:
      1.   Street curb intersections shall be rounded by radii of at least
twenty feet (20') where local streets intersect with other local streets; and
shall be at least twenty five feet (25') at any intersection with a street of
higher classification.
      2.   The above minimum radii shall be increased when the smallest angle
of intersection is less than sixty degrees (60°).
   (G)   Lots:
      1.   The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the
location of the proposed subdivision and for the type of development
contemplated, provided that no residential lot shall contain less than seven
thousand five hundred (7,500) square feet in area.
      2.   Excessive depth in relation to width shall be avoided. (Appreciation
of 2 to 1 shall normally be considered as appropriate.)
      3.   Every lot shall abut on a street.
      4.   Lots for residential purposes shall be at least sixty feet (60')
wide at the building setback line in order to permit compliance with the side
yard requirements of the zoning title 1  and still be adequate for a building
of practicable width.
      5.   Double frontage lots and reversed frontage lots shall not be platted
except as hereinbefore permitted under subsections (G)2 and (G)3 of this
section.
      6.   Side lot lines shall be approximately at right angles to the right
of way line of the street on which the lot abuts.
      7.   Corner lots for residential use shall be platted at least seventy
five feet (75') wide in order to permit conformance with the setback on the
side street required by the zoning title.
      8.   Residential lots fronting or abutting on major streets shall have a
minimum setback distance or front yard depth of at least ten feet (10') greater
than otherwise required.
   (H)   Utility Location:
      1.   Water, sanitary sewer and storm drains shall be located within the
street right of way. As built plans will be provided to the office of the city
engineer and shall show the dimensioned location of all private sewer and water
taps. (Ord. 726, 7-17-1979)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 10 of this code.
CHAPTER 10

SECTION:

   PREAPPLICATION PROCEDURE
   (Optional but strongly recommended)
1.   Landowner investigates possibility of development.
         (a)   Market analysis;
         (b)   Availability of utilities;
         (c)   Subdivision regulation review.
2.   Prepare tentative sketch plan (layout of streets).
3.   Review sketch plan with city engineer (check against master plan and
zoning map).
   SUMMARY OF PRELIMINARY PLAT PROCEDURE
1.   Engage engineer or land surveyor to prepare preliminary plat.
2.   Make application with the city engineering department for preliminary plat
approval, submit fifteen (15) copies of plat documents and pay application fee
($50.00).
Preliminary plat documents include:
         (a)   Street and lot layout;
         (b)   Vicinity sketch;
         (c)   Existing and proposed utility layout;
         (d)   Topography map;
         (e)   Street cross section;
         (f)   Design criteria for storm drains and sanitary sewers;
         (g)   Notes of commitment to install other required improvements not
shown on drawings; and
         (h)   Zoning.
3.   City engineering department places the preliminary plat on joint planning
and zoning commission agenda for review at its next regular public hearing
scheduled no less than three (3) weeks following application date.
4.   City engineering department distributes copies of preliminary plat to
other agencies for review, comment and information.
5.   City engineering department reviews comments returned from other agencies.
6.   City engineering department reviews preliminary plat against department
checklist.
7.   City engineering department summarizes findings and submits written report
to joint planning and zoning commission prior to meeting at which preliminary
plat is to be considered.
8.   Notices sent to owners of adjacent unplatted land of hearing pending.
9.   Joint planning and zoning commission reviews preliminary plat and engineer
report.
10.   Joint planning and zoning commission renders recommendation.
11.   Joint planning and zoning commission forwards recommendation to city
council accompanied by staff report.
12.   City council approves or amends joint planning and zoning commission
recommendations.
13.   If approved by city council, said approval will be noted on copies of the
preliminary plat along with conditions stipulated, if any, and attested to by
the city clerk.
14.   Copies of approved preliminary plat with approval noted thereon will be
distributed to the developer and public works department.
15.   If not approved by city council the developer will be notified by mail of
such disapproval with reasons stipulated.
16.   Developer secures permits for construction of required improvements.
   SUMMARY OF FINAL PLAT PROCEDURE
1.   Approval of preliminary plat.
2.   Completion of construction plans for streets and utilities of part to be
developed and submit to city engineer for approval and estimate of costs.
3.   Completion of final plat of part to be developed and submit five (5)
copies for approval to the city clerk and pay application fee ($10.00 plus
$2.00 per lot).
4.   City engineering department places final plat on joint planning and zoning
commission agenda for review at its next regular meeting scheduled no less than
three (3) weeks following application date.
5.   Developer submits bond or escrow in amount estimated by city engineer to
cover cost of required improvements.
6.   Bond reviewed by city engineer and city attorney.
7.   City engineering department submits written report to joint planning and
zoning commission prior to meeting at which final plat is to be considered.
8.   Joint planning and zoning commission reviews final plat and reports from
city engineer and renders recommendation to city council. (A recommendation for
unconditional approval includes authorization for chairman and secretary of
joint planning and zoning commission to sign plat attesting to joint planning
and zoning commission approval.)
9.   City council considers report and recommendation of joint planning and
zoning commission and approves, disapproves, or conditionally approves final
plat.
10.   Unconditional approval by city council includes authorization for mayor
and city clerk to sign plat attesting to approval and acceptance of
dedications.
11.   Conditional approval by city council requires that all conditions
stipulated be complied with before any of the authorized signatures will be put
on the final plat.
12.   If final plat is disapproved, the developer shall be notified in writing
with reasons for such disapproval listed.
(Ord. 726, 7-17-1979; amd. Ord. 3041, 12-3-2013)
